intro: Micromeria nervosa subsp. rodriguezii, commonly known as the Rodriguez's narrowleaf micromeria, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Geraniaceae and is characterized by its small, narrow leaves and clusters of tiny, white to pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, such as rocky slopes and sandy soils, and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its botanical features include glandular hairs on the stems and leaves, which contribute to its aromatic properties. The subspecies is distinguished by its slightly broader leaves and more elongated inflorescences compared to other members of the species.
